The system must be maintainable and adaptable to evolving stakeholder needs.

System must support edge and fog computing to enable distributed intelligence and real-time decision-making.
Software must support the implementation and operation of DPPs (Digital Product Passports) as mandated by regulations like the Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR).

Specifically for the battery industry, software must be able to manage a DBP (Digital Battery Passport) for certain batteries by February 2027. This includes handling over 100 static and dynamic data points to track, monitor, and manage batteries throughout their lifecycle.
Software used for reporting must be accurate to prevent flawed reports, which can lead to penalties for the company and legal liability for its management.

Software systems need to enforce transparency in carbon footprint reporting and manage due diligence obligations for sourcing raw materials like lithium and cobalt, as required by the EU Battery Regulation.
Software should collect and analyze environmental data, such as energy consumption and emissions, across a product's entire lifecycle
Development should use techniques like Dynamic Power Management (DPM) for mobile systems and avoid "software bloat" that increases energy use.

Software should be designed to support a circular economy by promoting the reuse of products and resources. This includes improving recycling efficiency and enabling second-life applications for products like batteries

Development practices should avoid unnecessary features, referred to as "software waste," and promote the reuse of both software and data. Improved software maintainability is also key, as it extends the application's longevity and reduces overall resource consumption.
Green Software Engineering can reduce IT costs through resource-efficient architectures like cloud computing. Using open-source software can lower licensing costs
Software should be designed inclusively and promote equality and health.
Software can be designed to foster a sense of community and participation. Features that enhance communication can strengthen customer relationships and positively influence the broader community.
The system should not have issues after updates, such as unwanted changes to permissions or settings.
There must be clear plans and policies for data management, privacy, security, and compliance with e-health laws and standards.
All relevant stakeholders (e.g., physicians, nurses, pharmacists) must be involved in the planning and selection process to ensure the chosen system meets their needs
The organization's underlying infrastructure (e.g., networks, servers, equipment) must be ready and capable of operating the e-health solution effectively.
The organization must be able to cover all expenses, including not just the initial purchase but also operational costs and potential upgrades
Widgets shall use as much screen area as possible to be hit easily, in accordance with Fitts Law, which states that the time to reach a target depends on its distance and size
Widgets that are meant to be clicked sequentially shall be placed close to each other.
Frequently-executed I/O-intensive workloads shall be reduced.

Buffer management shall be applied using batch replacement policies to make use of sequential I/O and improve the performance of graphic databases (e.g., a news wall that requires constant refreshing).
Fields with a known number of characters (like phone numbers or dates) shall use automatic jumping of the cursor to the next item
User interaction shall be simplified to improve the latency caused by human interfacing.
A tradeoff shall be achieved between the number of navigation levels and the number of elements on each level.
Fine patterns and textures shall be minimized to reduce switching activity.
Systems must be able to interconnect through "open" interfaces and facilitate the exchange of health-related information.
Systems must not only exchange data but also understand it, which requires a "common language" achieved through standardized coding and data representation.
Systems must be transparent, private, and secure. Any innovation must be reliable in protecting patient privacy and upholding ethical standards

Sustainable healthcare organizations require effective knowledge management systems to support performance and innovation. This includes building a proper infrastructure to support Evidence-Based Medicine.
The application must have an authentication procedure , allowing users to choose whether to be authenticated and to log in via credentials or social media.
Users should be able to manage their personal health record, which includes the ability to edit, add, remove, share, import, export, and back up their health data.
The app must promote interaction among users through social networks or online health forums.
It should be available in multiple languages and allow users to switch between them easily
The app shall help reduce transportation by allowing users to find nearby healthcare centers.
Users must be able to edit data offline, and the app must save these changes locally
The app must easily adapt to future operating system (OS) changes by respecting mobile OS development guidelines

Define acceptable thresholds for CPU, memory, and storage usage to promote efficient hardware utilization.
Set objectives for the software's maintainability, modularity, and code complexity to ensure its long-term adaptability and efficiency.
Develop algorithms that optimize motion planning and task scheduling to reduce power usage.

The software should enable and control low-power or
 idle states for the robot. This allows the robot to
 automatically enter a power-saving mode when not actively performing a task.
Design cloud applications to be loosely coupled and efficient to reduce resource consumption.
Schedule workloads in a way that minimizes heat generation and avoids hotspots, reducing the load on cooling systems.
Use virtualization technologies (like VM migration, consolidation, and load balancing) to reduce the number of active physical machines, thus saving energy.
The system must operate reliably without on-site personnel, automatically handling anomalies and failures to prevent outages and equipment damage.
The system must efficiently manage and share resources across distributed sites to handle fluctuating demand and improve overall resource utilization.
The system must be able to utilize diverse energy sources (renewable and grid), varied pricing, and different cooling technologies to optimize for both cost and energy consumption.
The infrastructure should intelligently interact with the smart grid, using stored energy during peak price hours and charging during off-peak times to reduce operational costs.
Infrastructure, particularly cooling systems, must be compact to fit into space-constrained urban environments.
Provide comprehensive and transparent sustainability reports to stakeholders, validated by third-party verification.
Implement real-time environmental performance monitoring to enable continuous optimization.
Provide firmware and software updates to enhance the functionality and extend the competitive lifespan of older devices.
The system should be generic enough to minimize the need for extensive customization for different nationalities.
The e-learning system must be relevant to the different social, cultural, and ethical backgrounds of its global users.
User autonomy to configure resource-saving settings.
Backward compatibility when releasing new versions.
The system should not impede the social relationships and community values that are part of traditional education.
he system must be sensitive to and accommodate social customs, especially regarding privacy and virtual participation.
The system must account for students' varying abilities to self-teach and not place the entire burden of learning on them and their parents.
The system must ensure equal rights of access and quality of education, regardless of geographic location, ICT readiness, or economic status.
The system must be designed with an understanding of diverse family economic situations, parental literacy, and the availability of support and equipment.
The implementation should be guided by various governance theories, including adaptive, network, collaborative, and accountable governance.

Enterpreneurship education training system should be inclusive and specifically target low-income individuals, women/girls, minorities, migrants, and victims of conflict to advance SDGs related to poverty and inequality (SDGs 1, 5, 10).
Enterpreneurship education training system should focus on building a socially and ecologically aware mindset among learners and teachers.
Optimized thermal, acoustic, and lighting performances.
Minimization of negative social impacts related to materials used and human rights.
Minimization of economic impacts during the design phase.
The software design process must intentionally and explicitly account for a diverse range of users, abilities, and cultural contexts to avoid unintentional exclusion.
Evaluating the environmental impact, such as energy consumption, as a key factor in determining software quality.
Leveraging open-source software to reduce the need for new development through reuse and modification.
Ensuring software is accessible and usable for all users, including those with disabilities, and respecting user privacy through ethical data practices.
Applications must have energy use requirements.
The system shall communicate to the user as much information about resource consumption as possible.
When a user's resource consumption is approaching the maximum target for that resource, a notification will be sent to the user.
The system shall display the average and minimum amounts for each type of resource consumed by previous users.
The system shall provide a form of incentive to encourage the user to reduce their resource consumption.
The system shall keep track of a user's/business's consumption of the specified resources.
The system shall only track resources in situations specified by the user.
The system shall test for accuracy of recorded resources on a monthly basis.
The system must account for uncertainties such as customer preferences and behaviors, market dynamics, and rebound effects.
Software execution must conserve resources by minimizing I/O calls and memory access, using concurrent models, reducing data size, and using offloading.
Reduce page load times through efficient resource usage, lightweight frameworks, and media optimization.
Use system fonts to eliminate additional downloads.
Optimize media assets through compression and incorporate user settings for lower data consumption.
Minimize the use of external libraries and hard-code web pages where possible to reduce server load.
Optimize database queries.
Use of advanced, sustainable architectures like evolutionary Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA).
The software must be a safe long-term investment, with minimized economic risks.
The software should maintain social capital, preserve community unity, and allow for participation and interaction
The software must be usable for a long time, even with changing requirements, and be easy to customize, reuse, adapt, and modify.
Provide timely feedback to users and follow regulatory standards.
Design easy-to-learn, user-friendly software that enhances users' ICT literacy.
Design software that helps users achieve their goals while reducing stress and frustration.
Mitigate the negative impacts of the software on society and a person's sense of belonging.
Ensure sensitive data protection and compliance with privacy regulations.
Provide information about community facilities to help users make informed decisions about where to live.
Develop features that enable technology sharing with other municipalities.
Ensure compatibility with assistive technologies like screen readers.
Take into account the projected service time of the software and plan for it to run on older hardware to prevent the disposal of existing equipment.
Steer clear of screens with bright colors or colors that could be harmful to the user's eyes.
Focus on minimizing waste throughout all software processes and the product life cycle.
Robotic software must support at least three energy modes (Normal, Eco, Low-power) and report mode with timestamp.
System reports estimated operational cost per mission (energy, consumables, maintenance amortized) and alerts if cost  is greater than budget threshold.
GUI/teleoperation must meet basic accessibility (keyboard-only control, screen-reader labels) and pass WCAG-level checks for operator screens.
System organized into modules with clear interfaces; each module has automated unit and integration tests
